entry.title: Ben Shapiro DESTROYS and OBLITERATES the Coding Interview

link.title: Ben Shapiro DESTROYS and OBLITERATES the Coding Interview

entry.content:
Iâ€™ve been interviewing again recently and I wanted to share all the technical questions Iâ€™ve ever received so that you too can annihilate and commit genocide on technical interview questions.

First I wanted to share some thoughts on the general process. If youâ€™re an interviewer, please:

  1. Donâ€™t schedule a call just to reject me, I donâ€™t want an email that just says you have â€œa quick updateâ€ but youâ€™d â€œrather speak on the phoneâ€.

  2. Do tell me a did a great job, even if I was mediocre.

  3. Do give me problems that I find challenging but that I ultimately solve. Make their difficulty just within reach so I feel really good about solving them. That psychological calculation also tells me that Iâ€™m â€œlucky to work hereâ€ because I â€œbarely made itâ€ rather than a super easy problem that doesnâ€™t make me feel special.

  4. Donâ€™t be offended if I try to squeeze everything from this offer I possibly can.

  5. Donâ€™t tell me you have my best interests at heart. Your goal as a recruiter is to make me sign and give me as little information as you can get away with. If I find out I donâ€™t like something after Iâ€™ve started Iâ€™m more likely to try to live with it.

  6. Donâ€™t hire me. Whereâ€™s your diversity? I am a child.

A good interview will scale the level of difficultly and make the candidate feel accomplished at every step, like a good video game (that is, only if you actually want to hire him/her/them).

Make me feel special, lure me in, then wring me out.

Just because theyâ€™re listed here doesnâ€™t mean I can solve them. Iâ€™ll keep adding to this list as I get more questions (which will hopefully be very rarely, interviewing is no fun). The Questions (in no particular order):

Multiplication Table

Print an n by n multiplication table, keep the widths of the columns consistent.

Calculator

Evaluate a mathematical expression like 1 + 3 * 2 and respect the traditional order of operations. This is sometimes given with / without parenthesis, but you generally just do this.

PIN Check

Write a function that lives on an embedded device that checks if a given pin is equal to a stored pin. This might seem easy at first but it was asked from a security point-of-view so it needed to be resistant against timing and power-glitching attacks (and maybe more that I donâ€™t know about).

Leader Board

Write a data structure to hold a leader board for a video game. You must be able to efficiently insert and update a playerâ€™s score and efficiently retrieve the nth best player.

String Subset

Given a list of (English) words and a set of characters, which word is the shortest and uses all the characters in the set? What if this wasnâ€™t just English?

Duplicate Strings

Given a large text find duplicate sections larger than k characters within it (efficiently, of course). If k = 3 and the text was â€œsea shells by the seashoreâ€ then sea is a duplicate because its at least k characters and appears more than once. You should be able to do this in linear time.

LRU Cache

I got this one twice already! This is a cache that has a limited capacity n, it will cache that many values until the limit is reached. If the cache is over capacity it will drop its Least Recently Used (LRU) key. A use counts as retrieving or setting the value. Itâ€™s well-known that both operations of this cache (setting and getting) must preform in constant time and thereâ€™s many examples online of how to achieve this.

Median Across Lists

Given two sorted lists return the median you would get if you were to combine the two lists. This should be in logarithmic time.

Leaf to Leaf

Find the longest path in a tree from a root to a leaf, then find the longest path between leaves (without repeating edges of course). This is in linear time and lends itself well to recursion.

Breaking the Safe

A safe is guarded by a number pad that accepts a four digit pin. Thereâ€™s no â€œsubmitâ€ button though so as soon as you enter the correct four digits the safe will unlock. This means entering â€œ12345â€ will have the effect of attempting â€œ1234â€ and â€œ2345â€. Whatâ€™s the shortest string that brute-forces all combinations?

There is actually some graph theory behind this that I learned a while ago but I donâ€™t remember, but under some (all?) conditions it should be possible to find the minimum-length string. I wasnâ€™t given a time constraint here because of the limited solution space.

2 Sum Below

Given a list of numbers find the two largest numbers whose sum is below k.

Word Reverse

Reverse the order of words in a sentence, not the characters within the words. My favorite solution is in Haskell:

rev_words = unwords . reverse . words

This is easy so the usual follow-up is how to do it in constant space.

Find the Diff

Given two lists of integers, find the one element that is different in both of them.

This one is really instructive because you go from an n2-time solution all the way down to an nlogn and even n. You can also do this in n time and constant space!

Coin Change

Given a value v and a list of coin denominations find all the possible ways to represent v in the given denominations (the number of ways to make change for cash).

Grid Path

If you can only walk up and to the right on a two-dimensional grid, how many possible ways are there to get to (x, y)? Note that thereâ€™s a formula (close form) for this so technically this can be solved in constant time but Iâ€™ve never been asked to do that.

3 Sum

Given a list of numbers, find all triplets that sum to zero.

Fibonacci

Calculate the nth Fibonacci number. This is often asked in the form of â€œdo a slow recursive oneâ€, then â€œa fast recursive oneâ€, then a â€œfast non-recursive oneâ€. Although if you didnâ€™t know about recursion youâ€™d probably get to the answer they want quicker.

entry.title: To Have Zucked and Lost
entry.content:
I wake up at 6:45 A.M. in a hotel room and start following some people who look like me. Soon a herd of young early-twenty-somethings begins to form and amoebas its way across suburban Palo Alto. Weâ€™re all funneled by exceptionally loud organizers into a bus and driven to 1 Hacker Way, a.k.a. Zuck-town (or Zuckerberg, I guess). I sat next to a Journalism intern; he blew my mind by telling me that Facebook wants to hire journalists, but why? It was a different time.

Iâ€™m greeted by some really cool l33t playfully calling me a n00b, but itâ€™s too early and Iâ€™m too sensitive to being patronized. Would you greet your new employee with a reminder of how inexperienced they are?

They also had a pirate flag (yarggh maties!). I canâ€™t call it dumb because my workplace has a pirate flag, so Iâ€™ll call it a cheap appeal to make me forget that my work is at best meaningless and at worst spreading click bait and anti-vaxxer propaganda.

But the worst part of working at Facebook and the orientation were all these signs that made feel bad for not being as excited as they were to be there.

The also had Black Lives Matter signs mixed in, which is an excellent movement to support. They shouldâ€™ve destroyed all their signs except Black Lives Matter.

But apart from that we got:

  1. BUILD SOCIAL VALUE
  2. EXPECT TO FEEL DIFFERENT (like after eating the food?)
  3. MOVE FAST (like to the bathroom?)
  4. DOUBT YOUR DOUBTS
  5. PROCEED AND BE BOLD
  6. FOCUS ON IMPACT
  7. THIS IS YOUR COMPANY NOW
  8. NEW WAYS OF SEEING
  9. MAKE SPACE TO THINK
  10. BE THE NERD
  11. STAY FOCUSED AND KEEP SHIPPING
  12. NOTHING AT FACEBOOK IS SOMEBODY ELSEâ€™S PROBLEM
  13. BE OPEN

I mean BE OPEN? We were told on that stage to never talk to reporters, ever.

And Oh My Hashem, there was this one post with Mr. T on it that said â€œI pity the fool who doesnâ€™t use âŒ˜Tâ€, what does that mean? I donâ€™t have a mac but I assume it means open a new tab? What fresh hell of office humor is this? Why make someone feel bad about how they use a computer? Who would laugh at that? No one? Is that the point?

We recently bought a succulent and weâ€™re naming it â€œSuccerbergâ€. Every time I see it Iâ€™ll think of free food, meandering around the office, not working, and listening to The Adventure Zone. Thatâ€™s whatâ€™s so great about Facebook, thatâ€™s why you should work there.

That and $9,000 a month.

I was not asked to come back full-time.

entry.title: Talk to Me
entry.content:
Ms. Bronsonâ€™s eyes are tired, glazed red, and live in individual craters above her nose. It took all her strength to curl them away from her desk and onto Derl. She began in her signature slow southern drawl.

â€œVarmon? Would you like to share?â€

Derl Varmon stood up. His eyes were wide satellites, large and sensitive enough to absorb any signals of validation that might emit from Ms. Bronson. As he contorted his face in thought he garnered some attention as a rare and welcome source of entertainment. Reliable too, since heâ€™d been standing for a while.

â€œUhâ€¦â€

Derl frantically swam through a fecal ocean of answers, vision browned, swatting for a needle. As he stood, a layer of sweat condensed on his skin and gilded his forehead, his mouth opened but no word dared be the first. He bartered, begged, and clawed his mind for answers, but after some time he narrowed his eyes, dimmed his reception, and braced for Ms. Bronson.

â€œIâ€™ll repeat my question, Wâ€”â€

Then he felt it! Deep in his gut, oh wait, his mind: the feeling of confidence, of relief, of response. Syllables, words, then clauses poured out of his mouth as if his entire lunch became one thorough thought.

â€œSo slavery? Heh. Thatâ€™s what black people were at first, but not now. Now Iâ€™m really nice to them, heh, no I mean, whenever we look at someone we shouldnâ€™t see black, yellow, red, or brown, we shouldnâ€™t see anything. We have to move past that, we can all live equally now.â€

â€œMhmm. That was a very critical thought.â€

Derl sat, his ears vacuumed her praise. Seven words, ten syllables.

â€œRemember! Critical Thinking is a vitally important class, if you donâ€™t learn how to think critically now, howâ€™ll you get to a good college? So you can get a balanced job? So youâ€™ll have time for your family?â€

The classroom was silent. Most fell asleep during the video miniseries, but the students who felt too guilty about disrespecting Civil Rights instead grew resentful that the movement had such a soothing and monotone narrator. A few black students who made it through the video exchanged looks of disbelief. Derl returned a thumbs up and a smile in their direction, his face was excessively understanding.

â€œAâ€¦nyâ€¦oâ€¦neâ€¦? Varmon canâ€™t be the only one with opinions on African Americans.â€

The silence grew stronger. More confident in its identity now, it felt this time wouldnâ€™t be eclipsed by Bronson.

â€œOkay. Remember all yâ€™all have an essay on your opinion of the Civil Rights movement due tomorrow. Thatâ€™ll wrap up â€˜The American Race: A Race Against Timeâ€™â€¦ but Iâ€™ll give yaâ€™ll a sneak peak of our next unit â€˜Think like a Mathtermindâ€™. Hereâ€™s somethinâ€™ to get us thinking. Who can tell meâ€¦ the highest probability?â€

Derl heard a whisper immediately behind him.

â€œone point ohâ€

Startled, he left the comfort of Ms. Bronson to turn back and see an unremarkable JesÃºs Cabello. JesÃºs returned him a vacant, uncomfortable look. Derl slowly turned back around, he knew the face of his enemy. The whisper, however, tapered into nothing a few desks away from Derl, allowing Silence to blanket the room again. It hoped dearly Bronson would collapse from her exhaustion, but underestimated her perseverance in reading lesson outlines.

â€œ1.0, for example, is a valid answer. Youâ€™ll soon see there are a lot of correct answers in Math, and they each can depend on your individual perspective! Now, who knows the probability of being completely uncertain about something?â€

Derl began mouthing through numbers, but he only finished a few before he heard it again, a little louder this time, and flinched.

â€œthe probability of being completely uncertain about something â€¦ one halfâ€

Derl slowly crumples his notebook paper containing some numbers below one, flicks it off his desk, and lands it perfectly on top of his thermos. A slight smile broke his stern face, and he relaxed some more in his chair. Bronson waits another minute, making a sizable dent in the twenty he had left.

â€œOne half! Thatâ€™s what youâ€™re all thinking right? That is right, but not always. Sometimes itâ€™s a quarter, sometimes an eighth, it can be an infinite number of answers! But think about that, one half and one point oh. Thereâ€™s not a lot of room between being sure of something and not being sure at all. Remember that when youâ€™re thinking critically, not just about math, but the news, your decisions, your lives.â€

â€œâ€¦your decisions, your livesâ€

JesÃºs repeated every word out of Bronsonâ€™s mouth, all but mocking her.

â€œIf you throw a ball on the floor, you have no way of knowing exactly where itâ€™s going to land. You might be able to know roughly where, but never precisely. But think about this, what would happen if we could know exactly where a ball lands? Could we win tomorrowâ€™s lottery? Make a perfect lie detector? Tell the future? What wonâ€™t we know? Thatâ€™s what a crack critical thinker should be consideringâ€¦â€

Derl listened closely, penciling, condensing, and internalizing all Ms. Bronson had to say. He had learned so much from her, his parents, his church, because nothing frightened Derl more than the â€˜Avoidable Mistakeâ€™. The mistake thatâ€™s haunted, in retrospect, everyone in history, since it teaches a trite and timeworn lesson that its transgressors only recognize too late. They wish they had listened to that one person about that one thing, it dangles what could have been everywhere they look, it taunts them. So, to reliably avoid that personal horror Derl, around the fifth grade, started keeping a notebook full of his mentorsâ€™ lessons, maybe he could do better than they:

  1. Wait until your one true love to lose your virginity, women can smell when youâ€™ve been with someone else.
  2. Sharing Younique cosmetics uplift, empower, and validate women everywhere, and let you earn a financial reward at the same time.
  3. The Secret contains life-changing tools to become your best self and reveal those pesky secrets of life.
  4. Love is all you need. As long as you love enough, you can survive heartbreak or a heart attack.
  5. Donâ€™t be a dawdling dingus, buy low, sell high!
  6. Donâ€™t listen to your father, earn some money so you can be happy, and have a happy family.
  7. You have to be careful when you say youâ€™re sure about something because one is very close to one half. You have to think critically about everything to really get to the bottom of it.

â€œâ€¦ But think about this! We know roughly where a ball will land. How is it that so many combinations of infinite possibilities end up so predictable? How do so many unique people end up so similar?â€

â€œâ€¦people end up SO SIMILARâ€

â€œCabello, would you â€“â€

â€œCabello, would youâ€

â€œâ€“ like to share?â€

â€œâ€“ like to share?â€

Bronsonâ€™s eyes widened and locked onto JesÃºs.

â€œCabello I expect you to â€“â€

â€œCabello I expect you toâ€

â€œâ€“ talk to meâ€“â€

â€œtalk to meâ€

â€œâ€“ like â€“â€

â€œlikeâ€

â€œâ€“ an â€“â€

â€œan adult.â€

Cabello ran ahead one word, but â€˜adultâ€™ was clearly next.

â€œâ€“ adult.â€

â€œCaâ€“â€

â€œCabello do not come in here and fuck with me. I know you, Iâ€™ve seen a lot of kids exactly like you. Hell your dad mows my lawn, and youâ€™ll be take over the business right? Youâ€™ll end up alone with that depressing job and a sorry life if you keep this up â€¦ youâ€™ll ruin any future you had left. Iâ€™m not getting anything out of this, Iâ€™ll be sitting here teaching, getting paid above minimum wage. Take this opportunity to do right by yourself and by your family. Or are you just going to give up, feel sorry, and lay bricks for the rest of your life? This is America son, you can make it, but only if you actually try a little.â€

â€œI donâ€™t have to listen to this, get the fuck out of my classroom!â€

Cabello ran an entire rant ahead. Bronson stared in disbelief at JesÃºs Cabello, who only returned an empty and hollow look. An uncomfortable silence reclaimed power over the room, but only held it for a few minutes. Then JesÃºs spoke.

â€œSomething really strange happened to me today.â€

â€œReally? God, right when I come home? Itâ€™s, uh, chicken and rice.â€

â€œThen what would you like?â€

â€œO.K. Chicken and rice.â€

JesÃºs paused for a few seconds, then continued.

â€œI wanted to tell you somethingâ€¦â€

â€œWait, would you listen? I have aâ€¦ Youâ€™re going to be a dad!â€

â€œI think about a month ago.â€

â€œWhat do you mean â€˜is it too lateâ€™? Weâ€™re not even consideringâ€“â€

â€œI thought youâ€™d be more excited.â€

â€œI know, yeah, that is more like you.â€

â€œI think baby Charlie â€™ll bring us closer, weâ€™ll be a complete family!â€

â€œYesterday.â€

â€œIâ€™m sorry. We talked about this, I thought we were on the same page.â€

â€œO.K. Iâ€™ll go next week.â€

â€œCharlie? Donâ€™t leave the table!â€

Another small pause.

â€œMom? Hi.â€

â€œHey mom, no, hang on.â€

â€œNo. Mom wait.â€

â€œI told Charlie, he didnâ€™t like it.â€

â€œI understand what heâ€™s sayinâ€™, but itâ€™s the wayâ€“.â€

â€œIs that how Dad took it?â€

JesÃºsâ€™ speech slowly sped up, finally reaching a terminal inhuman tempo. JesÃºs, or â€œThe Cantorâ€ as heâ€™s now known, became unintelligible. Those listening to his psalms could only glean the coarser details. Eventually his monologue of arguments became apologies, then pleads, then a probability lesson, and it began to follow some pattern of emotion. JesÃºs could fit everything Bronson would ever say into his sermon, her entire life painted in a single stroke by a small Hispanic boy. The classroom clockâ€™s minute hand bolted through years of life. As it reach the hour JesÃºsâ€™ voice grew raspy and frail, Derl could read the class was nearing its end. Then JesÃºs froze, gazing into a distant nothing, still and speechless. Quiet he stood for what, at this speed, mustâ€™ve been an eternity, until he collapsed on the floor. The bell rang.

Normally, as Ms. Bronson knew, collapsing on a stone floor is noiseless, but JesÃºs fell arms wide open on his long-unacquainted classmate next to him, unconscious. The girl below him woke up screaming, rolling his body off hers and allowing his head to thump on the stone floor. JesÃºs was a rag doll, his mouth firmly suctioned to the tiling.

â€œMs. Teacher you killed that poor boy!â€ She yelled, pointed and delegated to Bronson.

Ms. Bronson stood paralyzed staring at JesÃºs. Her stasis only broke a few seconds after the studentâ€™s loud and irritating scream. She grabbed her coat, attempted to excuse herself, and ran into a crowded hallway.

Derl still sat there, disappointed. Later an investigation revealed he was the only one awake through the entire hour. He recited his account to the school principal and a state detective:

â€œMs. Bronson asked a question, and then JesÃºs started acting up, like always. J.C. was just trying to get on Ms. Bronsonâ€™s nerves, and he did good too. Heh, he even pretended to go to boneless! But I didnâ€™t get to hear the rest of the lesson, I was taking notes, look!â€

â€œThanks!â€

â€œWell after that Ms. Bronson ran out.â€

â€œYeah, she left us.â€
